questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of difficulty swallowing food. Initially, only solid food was problematic, but liquids have also become more difficult to swallow over the last 2 months. She also reports occasional regurgitation of food when she lies down. The patient is an avid bird-watcher and returned from a 3-week trip to the Amazon rainforest 3 months ago. She has had a 3.5-kg (7.7-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. She has not had abdominal pain, blood in her stools, or fever. She underwent an abdominal hysterectomy for fibroid uterus 6 years ago. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.2 g/dL. A barium esophagram is shown. Esophageal manometry monitoring shows the lower esophageal sphincter fails to relax during swallowing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the chest and abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral medications, such as calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine), are the least effective treatment option for achalasia and should only be considered when other treatment options are unsuccessful or contraindicated. Because this patient has not undergone any prior treatment for achalasia, nifedipine is not the most appropriate step in management at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin injections are highly effective for treating any type of achalasia in patients who cannot undergo definitive treatment. However, the effects are temporary, and over 50% of patients require repeat treatment within 6–12 months. Since this patient has not received further evaluation or prior therapy for achalasia, botulinum toxin injection is not the most appropriate step in management at this time

C) CORRECT:

Upper endoscopy is indicated in patients with features of achalasia to rule out pseudoachalasia, which is caused by an underlying condition, such as esophageal cancer. This patient's smoking history and significant weight loss raise concern for malignancy, necessitating endoscopic inspection. If esophageal cancer is suspected, endoscopic ultrasound and biopsy should also be performed. After pseudoachalasia is ruled out, pneumatic dilation, laparoscopic Heller myotomy, or peroral endoscopic myotomy may be used as definitive treatment depending on the subtype of achalasia. If definitive treatment is not possible, an injection of botulinum toxin may be used.

D) INCORRECT:

Giemsa staining can be used to detect Chagas disease, which may manifest with megaesophagus and features of achalasia. Although this patient recently traveled to a region where Chagas disease is endemic, her symptoms started before the trip, and features of achalasia typically occur during the chronic phase 10–20 years after primary infection. Therefore, Chagas disease is an unlikely cause of her condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic Heller myotomy is a surgical procedure used for the definitive treatment of achalasia. This procedure is often combined with fundoplication to reduce the postoperative risk of gastroesophageal reflux disease. However, before proceeding with definitive treatment, pseudoachalasia must be ruled out in all patients with suspected achalasia.

F) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest and abdomen is indicated in the diagnostic staging of gastroesophageal cancers. Given the patient's smoking history and significant weight loss, malignancy should be ruled out. However, a CT scan of the chest and abdomen is not the preferred modality for ruling out malignancy.
questions.hint: The combination of dysphagia to solids and liquids, bird-beak sign on esophagram, and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter on manometry are indicative of achalasia.

questions.text: A previously healthy 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute retrosternal chest pain that radiates to his back. The pain started suddenly while he was having dinner. A few moments before the onset of the pain, he experienced discomfort when trying to eat or drink anything. On the way to the hospital, he took a sublingual nitrate tablet that he had at home, which helped relieve the pain. His pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 144/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm with no ST-segment abnormalities. An esophagogram shows areas of diffuse, uncoordinated spasms in several segments along the length of the esophagus. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Simultaneous multi-peak contractions on esophageal manometry
High lower esophageal sphincter pressure on esophageal manometry
Mass at the gastroesophageal junction on ultrasonography
Elevated CK-MB levels on serum studies
Significant ST-segment depression on exercise stress test

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Simultaneous multi-peak contractions on esophageal manometry are the characteristic finding of DES. Repetitive nonperistaltic, nonprogressive contractions impede the progression of solid and liquid foods down the esophagus, which classically leads to dysphagia and squeezing retrosternal chest pain, as seen in this patient. Symptoms and relieving factors (nitrates) of DES can closely resemble those of cardiac pathology. Therefore, acute coronary syndrome should always be ruled out before considering a gastrointestinal disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple mucosal erosions on endoscopy are consistent with reflux esophagitis caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). This condition can cause retrosternal pain that radiates to the back and, in some cases, dysphagia as seen in this patient. However, additional symptoms like regurgitation and nausea would also be present. Furthermore, in GERD, esophagogram may show strictures, ulcers, and gastric hernias due to gastroesophageal reflux, whereas the multiple areas of diffuse, uncoordinated spasms with segmentation seen in this patient are more consistent with DES.

C) INCORRECT:

High lower esophageal sphincter pressure on esophageal manometry is diagnostic of achalasia, which presents with progressive difficulty swallowing, retrosternal chest pain, and a foreign body sensation in the esophagus. However, this patient's sudden onset of symptoms while eating is not typical for achalasia. Also, the esophagogram findings in this patient are more consistent with DES.

D) INCORRECT:

A mass at the gastroesophageal junction on ultrasonography is suspicious for esophageal cancer. Patients typically present with dysphagia (for solids at first and liquids later), regurgitation, and systemic manifestations such as weight loss, fatigue, and anemia. This patient does not have systemic manifestations and esophagogram findings are more consistent with DES than esophageal cancer. If a mass were present, it would be seen as a narrowed asymmetrical lumen in the lower esophagus on esophagogram.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated CK-MB levels on serum studies are consistent with myocardial infarction. Although this patient has retrosternal chest pain radiating to the back, he lacks other symptoms like dyspnea, palpitations, diaphoresis, and typical findings on ECG. Furthermore, esophagogram results are consistent with DES.

F) INCORRECT:

Cardiac exercise stress test is used for diagnosis and prognosis of patients with anginal symptoms. If the patient has coronary artery disease (CAD), the atherosclerotic plaque would prevent sufficient blood required to meet the increased oxygen requirements from reaching the myocardium and thus show ST-segment depression on ECG. Although retrosternal chest pain that radiates to the back and is relieved with nitrates could be caused by CAD, such events would be independent of eating or drinking and more likely be triggered by exertion. Additionally, other features like palpitations, sweating, and dyspnea would likely also be present. CAD would not explain this patient's esophagogram results, which indicate DES.

G) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive contractions on esophageal manometry are consistent with hypertension peristalsis (nutcracker esophagus). Although this patient's chest pain while eating could suggest this diagnosis, the presence of diffuse, uncoordinated spasms with segmentation on esophagogram are more consistent with DES.
questions.hint: This patient has dysphagia to solids and liquids and his esophagogram shows a corkscrew or rosary bead appearance. These findings are suggestive of distal esophageal spasm (DES).

questions.text: A previously healthy 49-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of chest pain that radiates to her back. The pain started 45 minutes ago while she was having lunch. Over the past 3 months, she has frequently had the feeling of food, both liquid and solid, getting “stuck” in her chest while she is eating. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. An ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm with no ST-segment abnormalities. An esophagogram is shown. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Elevated lower esophageal sphincter pressure on manometry

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Simultaneous multi-peak contractions on esophageal manometry are the characteristic finding of DES. Repetitive nonperistaltic, nonprogressive contractions impede the progression of solid and liquid foods down the esophagus, which classically leads to dysphagia and/or a squeezing retrosternal chest pain, as seen in this patient. Medical treatment consists of calcium channel blockers, anticholinergics, or nitrates.

Symptoms and relieving factors (nitrates) of DES can closely resemble those of cardiac pathologies. Therefore, acute coronary syndrome should always be ruled out before considering a gastrointestinal disorder, especially if there are risk factors such as age > 45 years and hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple mucosal erosions on endoscopy are consistent with reflux esophagitis caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). This condition can cause acute retrosternal pain that radiates to the back and, in some cases, dysphagia. However, an esophagogram is usually normal in patients with GERD.

C) INCORRECT:

High pressure in the lower esophageal sphincter is diagnostic of achalasia, which can manifest with dysphagia to both solids and liquids as well as retrosternal chest pain. However, an esophagogram would show dilation of the pre-stenotic esophageal segment and a “bird-beak” appearance at the stenotic segment.
Image Description:

Barium swallow

Smooth funnel-shaped tapering (green overlay) in the region of the lower esophageal sphincter is accompanied by a widening (double-headed arrow) of the prestenotic distal esophagus (red overlay).

The appearance of the esophagus in achalasia is referred to as “bird-beak sign” (illustration). If the contour of the narrowed region is irregular and/or involves more than just the distal esophagus, the alternative diagnosis of esophageal carcinoma must be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

A mass at the gastroesophageal junction on imaging is consistent with esophageal adenocarcinoma, which can cause dysphagia. However, dysphagia associated with esophageal carcinoma worsens progressively (for solids at first and liquids later) and an esophagogram would usually show irregular, asymmetrical narrowing of the lumen at the distal esophagus (“apple-core” appearance). Moreover, other features suggestive of esophageal carcinoma (e.g., weight loss, fatigue, smoking history, alcohol consumption, history of chronic GERD) are not present in this patient.

A less common cause for a mass in the distal esophagus is an esophageal leiomyoma (benign tumor).

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive contractions on esophageal manometry are consistent with hypertension peristalsis (nutcracker esophagus), which can cause dysphagia and chest pain while eating. However, an esophagogram is usually normal in patients with a nutcracker esophagus.
questions.hint: The esophagogram in this patient with chest pain and dysphagia to solids and liquids shows a corkscrew or rosary bead appearance, which is typical of diffuse esophageal spasm (DES).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of difficulty swallowing solids and liquids. He points to the middle of his sternum, saying “I feel like food is getting stuck there.” He has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months and reports that his symptoms have progressively worsened over the same period. He also reports intermittent heartburn that is worse after drinking coffee. Treatment with over-the-counter pantoprazole has been ineffective. He has not had fever, chills, or night sweats. He underwent a cholecystectomy for cholecystitis 10 years ago and partial bowel resection for complicated sigmoid diverticulitis 5 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 35 kg/m2. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Barium esophagram shows dilation of the proximal esophagus with stenosis of the gastroesophageal junction. There is contrast pooling in the lower esophagus. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Outpouching of the upper esophageal wall

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Premature contraction of the esophagus is seen in corkscrew esophagus, which also manifests with dysphagia, globus sensation, and heartburn unresponsive to proton pump inhibitors. However, dysphagia in patients with corkscrew esophagus is usually intermittent and occurs predominantly to liquids. Moreover, a barium esophagogram would show a corkscrew appearance rather than a bird-beak sign.
Image Description:

Barium swallow

Helical contractions of the lower esophagus (green overlay), resulting in a corkscrew-like appearance.

Seen in patients with diffuse esophageal spasm (DES).

B) CORRECT:

Achalasia is caused by progressive degeneration of the esophageal myenteric plexus, resulting in dysfunctional peristalsis, increased resting pressure of the low esophageal sphincter (LES), and esophageal dilation proximal to LES. Patients usually present with a history of progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids, as seen in this patient, and regurgitation of food. Other common findings include heartburn unresponsive to proton pump inhibitors, and weight loss. In most patients with achalasia, the etiology is unknown (primary achalasia). Secondary achalasia is caused by conditions that compromise esophageal motility, such as esophageal cancer, stomach cancer, Chagas disease, amyloidosis, and sarcoidosis. All patients with achalasia should initially undergo an upper endoscopy to exclude a malignant cause. Esophageal manometry confirms the diagnosis of achalasia.
Image Description:

Barium swallow

Smooth funnel-shaped tapering (green overlay) in the region of the lower esophageal sphincter is accompanied by a widening (double-headed arrow) of the prestenotic distal esophagus (red overlay).

The appearance of the esophagus in achalasia is referred to as “bird-beak sign” (illustration). If the contour of the narrowed region is irregular and/or involves more than just the distal esophagus, the alternative diagnosis of esophageal carcinoma must be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis of esophageal smooth muscle is seen in patients with diffuse or limited systemic sclerosis. Smooth muscle fibrosis results in esophageal hypomotility and lower esophageal sphincter incompetence, which can also manifest as progressive dysphagia and dilation of the esophagus on a barium esophagogram. However, the gastroesophageal junction would be open rather than narrowed. Moreover, this patient does not have features of systemic sclerosis (e.g., thickened skin, sclerodactyly, hypomimia).

D) INCORRECT:

Outpouching of the upper esophageal wall is seen in patients with Zenker diverticulum (ZD), which manifests with dysphagia and globus sensation, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, patients typically present with a globus sensation in the neck region rather than retrosternally. Moreover, ZD usually manifests with regurgitation, halitosis, gurgling in the throat, and/or a mass in the neck, none of which are seen here. Finally, a barium esophagogram would show a contrast-filled pouch rather than a bird-beak sign.
Image Description:

The predominantely left-sided, dorsal contrast-filled structure in the upper esophagus most likely indicates Zenker diverticulum.

E) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic esophagitis can manifest with dysphagia and heartburn unresponsive to proton pump inhibitors, similar to what is seen here. However, a barium esophagogram would show formed rings or small strictures arranged in consequent ridges/furrows (a so-called "corrugated esophagus") but not a bird-beak sign.
questions.hint: This patient's barium esophagogram shows a bird-beak sign (dilation of the proximal esophagus with stenosis of the gastroesophageal junction), which suggests achalasia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of chest cramps after eating and progressively worsening difficulty swallowing solids and liquids. She sometimes regurgitates partially-digested foods and now mainly eats pureed meals. She has had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss during the past 6 months despite no change in appetite. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is a multivitamin. She smokes five cigarettes daily and drinks two glasses of wine on the weekends. She appears well. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (140 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Esophageal barium swallow shows dilation of the proximal esophagus with stenosis of the gastroesophageal junction and delayed barium emptying. An upper endoscopy shows normal esophageal and gastric mucosa without evidence of mechanical obstruction. Esophageal manometry shows uncoordinated peristalsis and increased resting lower esophageal sphincter pressure. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pharmacological treatment with nitrates is the least effective treatment for achalasia and is generally reserved for patients in whom all other treatment options are unfeasible or unsuccessful.

B) CORRECT:

Pneumatic dilation, laparoscopic Heller myotomy, and peroral endoscopic myotomy are the definitive treatment options for achalasia and are recommended in all patients without contraindications. The goal of these treatments is to mechanically disrupt LES muscle fibers and decrease resting pressure, thereby allowing the passage of ingested solids and liquids into the stomach. None of these treatments is curative, and patients often have recurrent symptoms that may require additional treatment.

Botulinum toxin injection in the LES is indicated in patients who cannot undergo definitive treatment. Injections are highly effective, but their effect is temporary. Oral medication with calcium channel blockers or nitrates is the least effective option and should only be considered if all other treatment options are unfeasible or unsuccessful.

C) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors (PPI), such as omeprazole, are appropriate for patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which can manifest with retrosternal chest pain, regurgitation, and dysphagia. Furthermore, a significant proportion of patients with GERD present with nonerosive reflux, and endoscopic findings that are typical in GERD (e.g., erythema, erosions) might be absent. However, this patient's esophageal manometry findings are most consistent with achalasia, for which PPI therapy is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin injections in the LES are an appropriate alternative for patients who have a high surgical risk (e.g., older age, significant comorbidities). However, the efficacy of botulinum toxin injections is lower than other treatment options, and more than 50% of patients require additional injections within 6–12 months. Therefore, in patients who have a low surgical risk (e.g., younger patients, no comorbidities), another step in management is preferred.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal stent placement is a palliative treatment for mechanical esophageal obstruction due to malignancy (e.g., esophageal cancer). This patient has no signs of mechanical obstruction or malignancy on upper endoscopy. Therefore, esophageal stent placement is not recommended.
questions.hint: This patient's history of regurgitation, heartburn, and progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids, along with bird beak sign on esophagogram and incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) on manometry are consistent with achalasia.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with a history of mild reflux esophagitis and mitral valve prolapse reports 6 months of worsening heartburn and regurgitation. She also reports that during the past 4 months, she has had difficulty swallowing both solid and liquid foods and has lost about 2.3 kg. She is currently taking omeprazole 20 mg daily. Five years ago, she underwent mitral valve repair.
On presentation, she has a heart rate of 80 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 127/75 mm Hg. Her physical examination is unremarkable. A barium-swallow study is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: CT of the chest and abdomen
Increase omeprazole to 20 mg twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When primary achalasia is the likely diagnosis, it should be confirmed with high-resolution esophageal manometry; therapy options include nifedipine, injection of botulinum toxin into the lower esophageal sphincter, pneumatic dilation of the lower esophageal sphincter, or Heller myotomy.

B) INCORRECT:

When primary achalasia is the likely diagnosis, it should be confirmed with high-resolution esophageal manometry; therapy options include nifedipine, injection of botulinum toxin into the lower esophageal sphincter, pneumatic dilation of the lower esophageal sphincter, or Heller myotomy.

C) INCORRECT:

Although esophageal manometry is the standard test for diagnosing achalasia, it cannot determine whether findings of aperistalsis and incomplete or failed relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) are due to achalasia or to pseudoachalasia. Therefore, the next appropriate step in management is upper endoscopy. If the endoscopy identifies a mass, CT is necessary for staging.

D) CORRECT:

The findings of a bird’s beak deformity and dilated esophagus on a barium-swallow study are indicative of a diagnosis of achalasia.

For newly diagnosed achalasia, pseudoachalasia and other structural diseases must be ruled out before confirming the diagnosis with manometry and initiating therapy, particularly if the patient is older, has a short duration of symptoms, or has been losing weight. Pseudoachalasia refers to diseases (e.g., malignancy, eosinophilic gastroenteritis, Chagas disease) that can cause esophageal motor abnormalities similar to primary achalasia.

Key learning point: Before diagnosing or initiating therapy in a patient with suspected achalasia, clinicians should first rule out pseudoachalasia and other structural diseases using upper endoscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

An increased omeprazole dose will not improve the achalasia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of mild reflux esophagitis and mitral valve prolapse reports 6 months of worsening heartburn and regurgitation. She also reports that during the past 4 months, she has had difficulty swallowing both solid and liquid foods and has lost about 2.3 kg. She is currently taking omeprazole. Five years ago, she underwent mitral valve repair. An esophageal barium swallow is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the chest and abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Achalasia should be considered in patients with suspected GERD that is unresponsive to proton pump inhibitor treatment (e.g., omeprazole). Increasing the dose will not improve achalasia.

B) INCORRECT:

CT of the chest and abdomen is indicated in the diagnostic staging of cancers of the esophagus and the stomach, which can manifest as pseudoachalasia. While this patient's symptoms are most likely caused by achalasia, a potential malignant underlying condition should be investigated. However, a CT scan of the chest and abdomen is not the method of choice for ruling out pseudoachalasia.

C) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine may be considered as a symptomatic treatment for achalasia if other measures are unsuccessful or contraindicated. Because this patient has not undergone any prior treatment for achalasia, nifedipine is not the most appropriate treatment at this time. Furthermore, potential causes of secondary achalasia should be evaluated before considering definitive treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Heller myotomy is a surgical procedure that is usually combined with fundoplication to prevent gastroesophageal reflux. Although this procedure is one of the first-line treatments for achalasia, potential causes of pseudoachalasia and other causes of obstruction should be evaluated before considering definitive treatment.

E) CORRECT:

For newly diagnosed achalasia, pseudoachalasia and other structural diseases must be ruled out before confirming the diagnosis with manometry and initiating therapy, particularly if the patient is older, has a short duration of symptoms, or has been losing weight. Pseudoachalasia refers to diseases (e.g., malignancy, eosinophilic gastroenteritis, Chagas disease) that can cause esophageal motor abnormalities similar to primary achalasia.

Key learning point: Before diagnosing or initiating therapy in a patient with suspected achalasia, clinicians should first rule out pseudoachalasia and other structural diseases using upper endoscopy.
questions.hint: Bird-beak sign and dilated esophagus on a barium swallow indicate achalasia.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents with a 4-month history of progressive difficulty swallowing affecting both solids and liquids. He experiences occasional chest pressure after meals and is awakened at night by episodes of coughing. He reports unintentional weight loss of 5 kg. He has not responded to over-the-counter antacids, and his symptoms have worsened despite dietary modifications. He denies any significant psychosocial stressors. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities in the oropharynx, and cardiorespiratory examination is normal. Basic laboratory tests, including complete blood count and serum electrolytes, are within normal limits. An upper endoscopy is planned.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic esophagitis often affects younger individuals with atopy or allergies. Dysphagia is usually intermittent and linked to food impactions, not the progressive difficulty seen here. The patient's age, weight loss, and lack of allergic history do not fit the typical profile of eosinophilic esophagitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Scleroderma affects the esophagus by causing fibrosis and decreased lower esophageal sphincter tone, leading to reflux. The patient's progressive dysphagia and weight loss suggest an obstructive or primary motility disorder rather than reflux. The absence of systemic features like skin thickening or Raynaud phenomenon further reduces the likelihood of scleroderma.

C) CORRECT:

Achalasia manifests with progressive dysphagia for both solids and liquids, indicating an esophageal motility disorder. The patient's chest discomfort after meals and nocturnal coughing suggest retained esophageal contents causing irritation and possible microaspiration. Achalasia results from degeneration of ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus, leading to aperistalsis and incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter. Diagnosis is confirmed through barium swallow, showing tapering at the gastroesophageal junction, and esophageal manometry, the gold standard. These clinical and diagnostic features align with the patient's presentation.

Key learning point: Achalasia is characterized by progressive dysphagia for both solids and liquids, chest discomfort, and nocturnal cough due to esophageal motility disorder and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax.

D) INCORRECT:

Diffuse esophageal spasm can present with dysphagia for solids and liquids and chest pain. However, it typically involves intermittent, non-progressive episodes, unlike the patient's steadily worsening symptoms. The episodic nature of this condition usually maintains nutritional status, making it inconsistent with the patient's weight loss and progressive dysphagia.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents with an 8-month history of progressive difficulty swallowing both solids and liquids. He has lost 5 kg and experiences frequent regurgitation of undigested food, especially at night. He describes a vague, squeezing sensation behind his sternum that intermittently disturbs his sleep. He avoids large meals and relies on soft foods to reduce discomfort. He has tried proton pump inhibitors without relief (see reports).

Upper endoscopy: No significant mucosal lesions
Chest X-ray: Widened mediastinum; no mass lesions

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diffuse esophageal spasm manifests with intermittent chest pain and dysphagia due to uncoordinated esophageal contractions. It typically presents episodically rather than progressively. The widened mediastinum, indicating esophageal dilation, is not common in diffuse esophageal spasm, which usually lacks significant structural changes.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal stricture often results from gastroesophageal reflux disease, leading to mucosal injury and scarring. It typically causes dysphagia for solids before liquids. The absence of mucosal lesions on endoscopy and the lack of response to proton pump inhibitors argue against this diagnosis. Additionally, esophageal stricture does not usually cause a widened mediastinum.

C) CORRECT:

Achalasia manifests with progressive dysphagia for both solids and liquids due to impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter and loss of peristalsis in the esophageal body. The patient's symptoms, including regurgitation of undigested food and weight loss, indicate esophageal dilation and stasis. The normal upper endoscopy excludes mucosal lesions, while the widened mediastinum on chest X-ray suggests esophageal dilation. These findings align with the pathophysiology of achalasia, where loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus leads to motility abnormalities.

Key learning point: Achalasia is characterized by esophageal dilatation, lack of peristalsis, and gradual narrowing at the lower esophagus, leading to symptoms of dysphagia, regurgitation, and retrosternal pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Scleroderma can cause esophageal motility disorders due to smooth muscle fibrosis, leading to dysphagia and reflux. However, it is usually accompanied by systemic features like skin changes and Raynaud phenomenon, which are absent here. The widened mediastinum is not typical of scleroderma, which primarily causes functional rather than structural esophageal changes.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old man presents with nine months of progressive difficulty swallowing both solids and liquids, frequent regurgitation of undigested material, occasional chest discomfort, and unintentional weight loss of about 5 kg. He has no significant comorbidities (see reports).

Upper endoscopy: No evidence of mucosal lesions or malignancy
Esophageal manometry: High resting pressure of the lower esophageal sphincter and failed relaxation during swallowing

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) such as lansoprazole reduce gastric acid secretion and are effective in acid-related conditions like gastroesophageal reflux disease. However, achalasia is a motility disorder characterized by impaired LES relaxation and esophageal dilation, not acid-mediated injury; PPIs do not address the underlying pathophysiology of achalasia.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) reduce LES pressure by inhibiting smooth muscle contraction, offering symptomatic improvement in mild achalasia or in patients unsuitable for definitive treatment. However, in advanced achalasia with high LES pressure and significant symptoms, a different first-line treatment is preferred.

C) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic botulinum toxin injection temporarily reduces LES pressure by inhibiting acetylcholine release. While it alleviates symptoms, its effects are transient, and repeated use can lead to antibody development further limiting its efficacy.

D) CORRECT:

Achalasia is characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax and abnormal esophageal motility, leading to progressive dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. Patients with achalasia should be offered definitive treatment to directly address the functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction. The type of definitive treatment depends on the type of achalasia; options include pneumatic dilation, laparoscopic Heller myotomy, and peroral endoscopic myotomy. Pneumatic dilation involves using an endoscopically guided balloon to disrupt the circular muscle fibers of the LES, decreasing resting pressure and improving esophageal emptying. Pharmacological treatment (e.g., calcium channel blockers, botulinum toxin injection) is considered if definitive treatment options are contraindicated or unsuccessful.

Key learning point: Pneumatic dilatation is considered an effective treatment for achalasia, providing relief by forcibly dilating the lower esophageal sphincter.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of worsening heartburn and regurgitation. Over the past 4 months, she has developed difficulty swallowing both solid and liquid foods and has lost about 2.3 kg. Her medical history includes mild reflux esophagitis and mitral valve prolapse. She is currently taking omeprazole and underwent mitral valve repair 5 years ago. An esophageal barium swallow is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the chest and abdomen.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The 2020 Canadian Association of Thoracic Surgeons (CATS) guidelines recommend against the use of medical treatments for achalasia, including calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine), as first-line therapy due to insufficient evidence supporting their effectiveness. Furthermore, potential causes of secondary achalasia should be evaluated before considering definitive treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Heller myotomy is a surgical procedure that is usually combined with fundoplication to prevent gastroesophageal reflux. Although this procedure is one of the first-line treatments for achalasia, potential causes of pseudoachalasia and other causes of obstruction should be evaluated before considering definitive treatment.

C) CORRECT:

For newly diagnosed achalasia, pseudoachalasia and other structural diseases must be ruled out before confirming the diagnosis with manometry and initiating therapy, particularly if the patient is older, has a short duration of symptoms, or has been losing weight. Pseudoachalasia refers to diseases (e.g., malignancy, eosinophilic gastroenteritis, Chagas disease) that can cause esophageal motor abnormalities similar to primary achalasia.

Key learning point: Before diagnosing or initiating therapy in a patient with suspected achalasia, clinicians should first rule out pseudoachalasia and other structural diseases using upper endoscopy.

D) INCORRECT:

Achalasia should be considered in patients with suspected GERD that is unresponsive to proton pump inhibitor treatment (e.g., omeprazole). Increasing the dose will not improve achalasia.

E) INCORRECT:

CT of the chest and abdomen is indicated in the diagnostic staging of cancers of the esophagus and the stomach, which can manifest as pseudoachalasia. While this patient's symptoms are most likely caused by achalasia, a potential malignant underlying condition should be investigated. However, a CT scan of the chest and abdomen is not the method of choice for ruling out pseudoachalasia.
questions.hint: Bird-beak sign and dilated esophagus on a barium swallow indicate achalasia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 4-month history of difficulty swallowing that has progressively worsened. Initially, he had trouble with solid foods, but over the past month, he reports equal difficulty swallowing both solids and liquids. He experiences regurgitation of undigested food particles, particularly when lying down at night, and cramping chest discomfort during meals. He has lost 18 lb (8.2 kg) during this time. Physical examination shows no palpable neck masses or lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct - The progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids, regurgitation of undigested food, cramping retrosternal pain during meals, and significant weight loss are classic features resulting from inadequate lower esophageal sphincter relaxation and impaired esophageal emptying due to degeneration of inhibitory neurons.

B) INCORRECT:

Zenker diverticulum can cause dysphagia and regurgitation of undigested food, but typically occurs in older patients and is often associated with halitosis and may be associated with a neck mass. The dysphagia to solids and liquids is more suggestive of a motility disorder than a structural abnormality.

C) INCORRECT:

While esophageal carcinoma can cause pseudoachalasia with similar symptoms, the 4-month progressive course in a relatively young patient and the classic pattern of dysphagia to both solids and liquids with regurgitation of undigested food is more consistent with primary achalasia.

D) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic esophagitis typically causes dysphagia and food bolus impaction in younger patients, but is commonly associated with atopic features such as asthma, rhinitis, or food allergies. The absence of these allergic features and the pattern of equal difficulty with both solids and liquids make eosinophilic esophagitis less likely in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

GERD typically presents with retrosternal burning pain and regurgitation, often worsened by lying down after meals. While GERD can cause dysphagia, the difficulty swallowing both solids and liquids, absence of typical heartburn, and significant weight loss are more characteristic of a motility disorder than reflux disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive difficulty swallowing solids and liquids over the past 4 months. She has lost 4 kg (9 lb) during this period. There is no history of serious illness. She emigrated to the US from Panama 7 years ago. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a systolic murmur and an S3 gallop. A barium radiograph of the chest is shown. Endoscopic biopsy of the distal esophagus is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Atrophy of esophageal smooth muscle cells
Infiltration of eosinophils in the epithelium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Loss of esophageal smooth muscle is commonly seen in patients with diffuse or limited systemic sclerosis. Loss of muscle results in esophageal hypomotility and lower esophageal sphincter incompetence, which can manifest as progressive dysphagia and dilation of the esophagus on a barium esophagram. However, the gastro-esophageal junction would be open rather than narrowed. Moreover, this patient does not have features of systemic sclerosis (e.g., thickened skin, sclerodactyly, mask-like facies).

B) INCORRECT:

Intranuclear basophilic inclusions are aggregates of viral replication-associated proteins commonly seen in CMV infections. CMV esophagitis can cause dysphagia, which is seen in this patient. However, CMV would not cause achalasia and only rarely leads to cardiomyopathy. Furthermore, most patients presenting with CMV esophagitis are immunocompromised, with CD4 counts ≤ 50. This patient's relatively unremarkable medical history suggests that she is immunocompetent.

C) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of eosinophils in the epithelium is the hallmark of eosinophilic esophagitis, which is often seen in patients with atopic tendency. It is characterized by mucosal fragility and inflammation, which can manifest with dysphagia. A barium esophagram or endoscopy may reveal formed rings or small strictures arranged in consequent ridges/furrows ("corrugated esophagus"), but not esophageal dilation. Furthermore, eosinophilic esophagitis is not associated with dilated cardiomyopathy.

D) CORRECT:

Chagas disease is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi infection, a parasite endemic to regions of Central and South America. In addition to dilated cardiomyopathy, T. cruzi infection can lead to denervation and destruction of myenteric plexus neurons anywhere along the gastrointestinal tract. This results in an inability to relax the lower esophageal sphincter (achalasia), which manifests as progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and a bird-beak sign on barium swallow.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of metaplastic columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus is a hallmark of Barrett esophagus. This condition is characterized by the transformation of stratified squamous epithelium to metaplastic columnar epithelium after the esophageal mucosa is chronically exposed to stomach acid in GERD. This patient has no history of retrosternal pain (heartburn), which would potentially indicate GERD. Furthermore, Barrett esophagus is not typically associated with cardiomyopathy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an esophageal tissue biopsy specimen (H&E stain; intermediate magnification)

The upper right edge of the image shows physiological multilayered squamous epithelium of the esophageal mucosa (white overlay), which changes into metaplastic prismatic epithelium with goblet cells (Barrett metaplasia; yellow overlay) toward the center of the image. Barrett metaplasia can eventually develop into epithelial dysplasia and, further, to adenocarcinoma of the esophagus (blue overlay). The carcinoma is characterized by loss of tissue architecture (atypical to absent gland formation) and invasive growth.

questions.hint: Clinical features of dilated cardiomyopathy (e.g., systolic murmur due to mitral regurgitation, S3 gallop) in a patient from Central America is suggestive of Chagas disease.
